para.sentence: (For other notation see LABEL:about.notations.)
real variable.
complex variable.
real or complex order.
integer order.
nonnegative integer.
arbitrary small positive constant.
Unless indicated otherwise, primes denote derivatives with respect to the argument.
Principal values correspond to principal values of (\tfrac{1}{2}z)^{\nu+1} ; compare §LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG.
The expansions (LABEL:eq:ST.SE.1) and (LABEL:eq:ST.SE.2) are absolutely convergent for all finite values of z.

\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(z\right)=\frac{2}{\pi}\left(z-\frac{z^{3}}{1^{2}\cdot 3^{2 }}+\frac{z^{5}}{1^{2}\cdot 3^{2}\cdot 5^{2}}-\cdots\right), , \mathbf{L}_{0}\left(z\right)=\frac{2}{\pi}\left(z+\frac{z^{3}}{1^{2}\cdot 3^{2 }}+\frac{z^{5}}{1^{2}\cdot 3^{2}\cdot 5^{2}}+\cdots\right).

Principal values of \mathbf{K}_{\nu}\left(z\right) and \mathbf{M}_{\nu}\left(z\right) correspond to principal values of the functions on the right-hand sides of (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.3) and (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.6).
Particular solutions: w=\mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(z\right),\mathbf{K}_{\nu}\left(z\right).
Particular solutions: w=\mathbf{L}_{\nu}\left(z\right),\mathbf{M}_{\nu}\left(z\right).
In this subsection A and B are arbitrary constants.
(LABEL:eq:ST.DE.7) applies when x is bounded, and (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.9) applies when x is bounded away from the origin.

(LABEL:eq:ST.DE.7a) applies when 0\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\pi and |z| is bounded. (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.8a) applies when -\pi\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq 0 and |z| is bounded. (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.9a) applies when \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|\leq\pi and z is bounded away from the origin.

(LABEL:eq:ST.DE.10) applies when |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi with |z| bounded. (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.11) applies when |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi with z bounded away from the origin.

subsection.title: Struve Functions
subsection.sentence: Figure 11.3.8: \left|\mathbf{K}_{0}\left(x+iy\right)\right| (principal value) for -8\leq x\leq 8 and -3\leq y\leq 3 . There is a cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 11.3.9: |\mathbf{H}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x+iy\right)| (principal value) for -8\leq x\leq 8 and -3\leq y\leq 3 . There is a cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 11.3.10: |\mathbf{K}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x+iy\right)| (principal value) for -8\leq x\leq 8 and -3\leq y\leq 3 . There is a cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 11.3.12: \left|\mathbf{K}_{1}\left(x+iy\right)\right| (principal value) for -8\leq x\leq 8 and -3\leq y\leq 3 . There is a cut along the negative real axis.

subsection.title: Modified Struve Functions
subsection.sentence: Figure 11.3.19: |\mathbf{M}_{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(x+iy\right)| (principal value) for -3\leq x\leq 3 and -3\leq y\leq 3 . There is a cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 11.3.20: |\mathbf{M}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x+iy\right)| (principal value) for -3\leq x\leq 3 and -3\leq y\leq 3 . There is a cut along the negative real axis.

para.sentence: For n=0,1,2,\dots , \mathbf{K}_{n+\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1 }{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{n}\frac{(2m)!\,2^{-2m}}{m!\,(n-m)!}\,(\tfrac{1}{2}z)^{n-2m} , \mathbf{L}_{n+\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=I_{-n-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)- \left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{n}\frac{(-1)^{m}(2m)!\,2 ^{-2m}}{m!\,(n-m)!}\,(\tfrac{1}{2}z)^{n-2m} , \mathbf{H}_{-n-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=(-1)^{n}J_{n+\frac{1}{2}}\left(z \right), , \mathbf{L}_{-n-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=I_{n+\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right).

\mathbf{H}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1}{ 2}}(1-\cos z), , \mathbf{H}_{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1} {2}}\sin z, \mathbf{L}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1}{ 2}}(\cosh z-1), , \mathbf{L}_{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1} {2}}\sinh z,

\mathbf{H}_{\frac{3}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{z}{2\pi}\right)^{\frac{1}{2 }}\left(1+\frac{2}{z^{2}}\right)-\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \left(\sin z+\frac{\cos z}{z}\right), \mathbf{H}_{-\frac{3}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1} {2}}\left(\cos z-\frac{\sin z}{z}\right), \mathbf{L}_{\frac{3}{2}}\left(z\right)=-\left(\frac{z}{2\pi}\right)^{\frac{1}{ 2}}\left(1-\frac{2}{z^{2}}\right)+\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \left(\sinh z-\frac{\cosh z}{z}\right), \mathbf{L}_{-\frac{3}{2}}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi z}\right)^{\frac{1} {2}}\left(\cosh z-\frac{\sinh z}{z}\right).
\mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(x\right)\geq 0, subject to x>0, \nu\geq\tfrac{1}{2}.

\mathbf{H}_{0}'\left(z\right)=\frac{2}{\pi}-\mathbf{H}_{1}\left(z\right), \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}(z\mathbf{H}_{1}\left(z\right))=z\mathbf{H}_{0} \left(z\right), \mathbf{L}_{0}'\left(z\right)=\frac{2}{\pi}+\mathbf{L}_{1}\left(z\right), \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}(z\mathbf{L}_{1}\left(z\right))=z\mathbf{L}_{0} \left(z\right).

For asymptotic expansions of zeros of \mathbf{H}_{0}\left(x\right) see ( ) .

In (LABEL:eq:ST.IR.11) and (LABEL:eq:ST.IR.12) the path of integration separates the poles of the integrand at s=0,1,2,\dots from those at s=-1,-2,-3,\dots.
If the series on the right-hand side of (LABEL:eq:ST.AE.1) is truncated after m(\geq 0) terms, then the remainder term R_{m}(z) is O\left(z^{\nu-2m-1}\right).
If \nu is real, z is positive, and m+\tfrac{1}{2}-\nu\geq 0 , then R_{m}(z) is of the same sign and numerically less than the first neglected term.
For re-expansions of the remainder terms in (LABEL:eq:ST.AE.1) and (LABEL:eq:ST.AE.2), see ( , p. 445) .

For the corresponding expansions for \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(z\right) and \mathbf{L}_{\nu}\left(z\right) combine (LABEL:eq:ST.AE.1), (LABEL:eq:ST.AE.2) with (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.3), (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.6), (LABEL:eq:BS.AEA.HE.4), and (LABEL:eq:BS.MAE.HE.1).

\int_{0}^{z}\mathbf{K}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t-\frac{2}{\pi}(\ln\left(2z \right)+\gamma)\sim\frac{2}{\pi}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{k+1}\frac{(2k)!(2k-1) !}{(k!)^{2}(2z)^{2k}}, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta, \int_{0}^{z}\mathbf{M}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t+\frac{2}{\pi}(\ln\left(2z \right)+\gamma)\sim\frac{2}{\pi}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(2k)!(2k-1)!}{(k!)^{2 }(2z)^{2k}}, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\delta, where \gamma is Euler’s constant (§LABEL:sec:GA.Def.EC).
More fully, the series (LABEL:eq:ST.SE.1) and (LABEL:eq:ST.SE.2) can be regarded as generalized asymptotic expansions (§LABEL:sec:AS.DEP.GAE).

Here c_{0}(\lambda)=1, c_{1}(\lambda)=2\lambda^{-2}, c_{2}(\lambda)=6\lambda^{-4}-\tfrac{1}{2}\lambda^{-2}, c_{3}(\lambda)=20\lambda^{-6}-4\lambda^{-4}, c_{4}(\lambda)=70\lambda^{-8}-\tfrac{45}{2}\lambda^{-6}+\tfrac{3}{8}\lambda^{- 4}.
These and higher coefficients c_{k}(\lambda) can be computed via the representations in ( ) .
For the corresponding result for \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(\lambda\nu\right) use (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.3) and (LABEL:eq:BS.AEO.DE.6).
See also ( , p. 336) .

For other integrals involving products of Struve functions see ( ) .
For integrals involving products of \mathbf{M}_{\nu}\left(t\right) functions, see ( , Appendix) .
The following Laplace transforms of \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(t\right) require \Re a>0 for convergence, while those of \mathbf{L}_{\nu}\left(t\right) require \Re a>1.

\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{2}{\pi \sqrt{1+a^{2}}}\ln\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}{a}\right), \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}\mathbf{H}_{1}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{2}{\pi a }-\frac{2a}{\pi\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}\ln\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}{a}\right), \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}\mathbf{L}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{2}{\pi \sqrt{a^{2}\!-\!1}}\operatorname{arcsin}\left(\frac{1}{a}\right) , \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}\mathbf{L}_{1}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t, =\frac{2a}{\pi\sqrt{a^{2}\!-\!1}}\operatorname{arctan}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{a^{ 2}\!-\!1}}\right)-\frac{2}{\pi a}.
For sums of Struve functions see ( , p. 456) and ( , §6.4.1) .
See also ( )
For properties of Struve functions of argument xe^{\pm 3\pi i/4} see ( ) .

The inhomogeneous Bessel differential equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\frac{1}{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{ \mathrm{d}z}+\left(1-\frac{\nu^{2}}{z^{2}}\right)w=z^{\mu-1} can be regarded as a generalization of (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.1).
For the foregoing results and further information see ( , §§10.7–10.73)and ( , §3.16) .

subsection.title: Expansions in Series of Bessel Functions

For fixed \mu and 
u , S_{{\mu},{
u}}\left(zight)\sim z^{\mu-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{k}a_{k}(- \mu,
u)z^{-2k}, subject to z	o\infty, |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta(<\pi).
For a_{k}(\mu,\nu) see (LABEL:eq:ST.LF.6).
If either of \mu\pm\nu equals an odd positive integer, then the right-hand side of (LABEL:eq:ST.LF.10) terminates and represents S_{{\mu},{\nu}}\left(z\right) exactly.

For uniform asymptotic expansions, for large \nu and fixed \mu=-1,0,1,2,\dots , of solutions of the inhomogeneous modified Bessel differential equation that corresponds to (LABEL:eq:ST.LF.1) see ( , pp. 388–390) .
For an error bound for (LABEL:eq:ST.LF.10) and an exponentially-improved extension see ( ) .
For further information on Lommel functions see ( , §§10.7–10.75)and ( , Chapter 3) .
For descriptive properties of s_{{\mu},{\nu}}\left(x\right) see ( ) .
Each is an entire function of z and \nu.
(LABEL:eq:ST.AWF.3) also applies when \Re z=0 and \Re\nu>0.

The Anger and Weber functions satisfy the inhomogeneous Bessel differential equation  rac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+ rac{1}{z} rac{\mathrm{d}w}{ \mathrm{d}z}+\left(1- rac{
u^{2}}{z^{2}}ight)w=f(
u,z), where f(
u,z)= rac{(z-

uight), subject to w=\mathbf{J}_{
u}\left(zight), or f(
u,z)=- rac{1}{\pi z^{2}}(z+
u+(z-
u)\cos\left(\pi
uight)), subject to w=\mathbf{E}_{
u}\left(zight).
These expansions converge absolutely for all finite values of z.

subsection.title: Graphics
subsection.sentence: Figure 11.10.1: Anger function \mathbf{J}_{\nu}\left(x\right) for -8\leq x\leq 8 and \nu=0,\frac{1}{2},1,\frac{3}{2} .
Figure 11.10.2: Weber function \mathbf{E}_{\nu}\left(x\right) for -8\leq x\leq 8 and \nu=0,\frac{1}{2},1,\frac{3}{2} .
Figure 11.10.3: Anger function \mathbf{J}_{\nu}\left(x\right) for -10\leq x\leq 10 and 0\leq\nu\leq 5 .
Figure 11.10.4: Weber function \mathbf{E}_{\nu}\left(x\right) for -10\leq x\leq 10 and 0\leq\nu\leq 5 .

para.sentence: \mathbf{J}_{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=\mathbf{E}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right) \\ =(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi z)^{-\frac{1}{2}}(A_{+}(\chi)\cos z-A_{-}(\chi)\sin z), , \mathbf{J}_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right)=-\mathbf{E}_{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right )\\ =(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi z)^{-\frac{1}{2}}(A_{+}(\chi)\sin z+A_{-}(\chi)\cos z), where A_{\pm}(\chi)=C\left(\chi\right)\pm S\left(\chi\right), \chi=(2z/\pi)^{\frac{1}{2}}.
For the Fresnel integrals C and S see §LABEL:sec:ER.DF.FI.

For n=1,2,3,\dots , \mathbf{E}_{n}\left(z\right)=-\mathbf{H}_{n}\left(z\right)+\frac{1}{\pi}\sum_{ k=0}^{m_{1}}\frac{\Gamma\left(k+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)}{\Gamma\left(n\!+\!\tfrac{ 1}{2}\!-\!k\right)}(\tfrac{1}{2}z)^{n-2k-1} , and \mathbf{E}_{-n}\left(z\right)=-\mathbf{H}_{-n}\left(z\right)+\frac{(-1)^{n+1}} {\pi}\sum_{k=0}^{m_{2}}\frac{\Gamma\left(n\!-\!k\!-\!\tfrac{1}{2}\right)}{ \Gamma\left(k+\tfrac{3}{2}\right)}(\tfrac{1}{2}z)^{-n+2k+1}, where m_{1}=\left\lfloor\tfrac{1}{2}n-\tfrac{1}{2}\right\rfloor, m_{2}=\left\lceil\tfrac{1}{2}n-\tfrac{3}{2}\right\rceil.

uight)}{\pi 
u}, \displaystyle\mathbf{E}_{
u}\left(0ight)= rac{1-\cos\left(\pi

u}.
, \displaystyle\mathbf{E}_{0}\left(z\right)=-\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(z\right), \displaystyle\mathbf{E}_{1}\left(z\right)=\frac{2}{\pi}-\mathbf{H}_{1}\left(z \right).
\mathbf{J}_{n}\left(z\right)=J_{n}\left(z\right), subject to n\in\mathbb{Z}.

Applications of Struve functions occur in water-wave and surface-wave problems ( ( ) and ( ) ), unsteady aerodynamics ( ( ) and ( ) ), distribution of fluid pressure over a vibrating disk ( ( ) ), resistive MHD instability theory ( ( ) ), and optical diffraction ( ( ) ).
More recently Struve functions have appeared in many particle quantum dynamical studies of spin decoherence ( ( ) ) and nanotubes ( ( ) ).
Subsequent subsections treat the computation of Struve functions.
The treatment of Lommel and Anger–Weber functions is similar.
For a review of methods for the computation of \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(z\right) see ( ) .
For simple and effective approximations to \mathbf{H}_{0}\left(z\right) and \mathbf{H}_{1}\left(z\right) see ( ) .

Although the power-series expansions (LABEL:eq:ST.SE.1) and (LABEL:eq:ST.SE.2), and the Bessel-function expansions of §LABEL:sec:ST.PPT.SB converge for all finite values of z , they are cumbersome to use when |z| is large owing to slowness of convergence and cancellation.
For large |z| and/or |\nu| the asymptotic expansions given in §LABEL:sec:ST.AE should be used instead.

For numerical purposes the most convenient of the representations given in §LABEL:sec:ST.IR, at least for real variables, include the integrals (LABEL:eq:ST.IR.3)–(LABEL:eq:ST.IR.7) for \mathbf{K}_{\nu}\left(z\right) and \mathbf{M}_{\nu}\left(z\right).
Subsequently \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(z\right) and \mathbf{L}_{\nu}\left(z\right) are obtainable via (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.3) and (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.6).
Other integrals that appear in §LABEL:sec:ST.IRA have highly oscillatory integrands unless z is small.
For complex variables the methods described in §§LABEL:sec:NM.QUA.CGAUSS andLABEL:sec:NM.QUA.RRAF are available.

A comprehensive approach is to integrate the defining inhomogeneous differential equations (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.1) and (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.4) numerically, using methods described in §LABEL:sec:NM.ODE. To insure stability the integration path must be chosen so that as we proceed along it the wanted solution grows in magnitude at least as rapidly as the complementary solutions.
Suppose \nu\geq 0 and x is real and positive.

Then from the limiting forms for small argument (§§LABEL:sec:ST.SE, LABEL:sec:BS.LF.ZE,LABEL:sec:BS.MLF.a),limiting forms for large argument (§§LABEL:sec:ST.AE.LA, LABEL:sec:BS.LF.ZI, LABEL:sec:BS.MLF.b), and the connection formulas (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.3) and (LABEL:eq:ST.DE.6), it is seen that \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(x\right) and \mathbf{L}_{\nu}\left(x\right) can be computed in a stable manner by integrating forwards, that is, from the origin toward infinity.
The solution \mathbf{K}_{\nu}\left(x\right) needs to be integrated backwards for small x , and either forwards or backwards for large x depending whether or not \nu exceeds \tfrac{1}{2}.
For \mathbf{M}_{\nu}\left(x\right) both forward and backward integration are unstable, and boundary-value methods are required (§LABEL:sec:NM.ODE.BVP).

Sequences of values of \mathbf{H}_{\nu}\left(z\right) and \mathbf{L}_{\nu}\left(z\right) , with z fixed, can be computed by application of the inhomogeneous difference equations (LABEL:eq:ST.RR.1) and (LABEL:eq:ST.RR.3).
There are similar problems to thosedescribed in §LABEL:sec:ST.COM.DE2 concerning stability.
In consequence forward recurrence, backward recurrence, or boundary-value methods may be necessary.
See §LABEL:sec:NM.LDE for implementation of these methods, and with the Weber function \mathbf{E}_{n}\left(x\right) as an example.
For tables before 1961 see ( ) and ( ) .
Tables listed in these Indices are omitted from the subsections that follow.

( , Chapter 12) tabulates \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right) , \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right)-Y_{n}\left(x\right) , and I_{n}\left(x\right)-\mathbf{L}_{n}\left(x\right) for n=0,1 and x=0(.1) 5, x^{-1}=0(.01)0.
2 to 6D or 7D.

( ) tabulates \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right) and e^{-x}\mathbf{L}_{n}\left(x\right) for n=0,1 and x=0(.001)5(.005)15(.01)10 0 to 11D. ( ) tabulates \mathbf{L}_{n}\left(x\right) for n=0,1 and x=0.2(.005)4(.05)10(.1)19.

2 to 5 or 6S, x=6(.25)59.5(.5)10 0 to 2S. ( ) tabulates \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right) for n=-4(1)15 and x=0.5(.5)2 6 to 8D or 9S. ( ) tabulates \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right) and \mathbf{L}_{n}\left(x\right) for n=-4(1)3 and x=0(1)20 to 8D or 7S.

( , Chapter 12) tabulates \int_{0}^{x}(I_{0}\left(t\right)-\mathbf{L}_{0}\left(t\right))\mathrm{d}t and (2/\pi)\int_{x}^{\infty}t^{-1}\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t for x=0(.1) 5 to 5D or7D; \int_{0}^{x}(\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)-Y_{0}\left(t\right))\mathrm{d}t-(2/ \pi)\ln x , \int_{0}^{x}(I_{0}\left(t\right)-\mathbf{L}_{0}\left(t\right))\mathrm{d}t-(2/ \pi)\ln x , and \int_{x}^{\infty}t^{-1}(\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)-Y_{0}\left(t\right)) \mathrm{d}t for x^{-1}=0(.01)0.
2 to 6D. ( ) tabulates \int_{0}^{x}\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t and e^{-x}\int_{0}^{x}\mathbf{L}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t for x=0(.001)5(.005)15(.01)10 0 to 11D.

( , Chapter 11) defines incomplete Struve, Anger, and Weber functions and includes tables of an incomplete Struve function \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x,\alpha\right) for n=0,1 , x=0(.2)1 0, and \alpha=0(.2)1.4,\tfrac{1}{2}\p i, together with surface plots.

( , pp. 416–421) gives Chebyshev-series expansions for \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right) , \mathbf{L}_{n}\left(x\right) , 0\leq\left|x\right|\leq 8 , and \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right)-Y_{n}\left(x\right) , x\geq 8 , for n=0,1 ; \int_{0}^{x}t^{-m}\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t , \int_{0}^{x}t^{-m}\mathbf{L}_{0}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t , 0\leq\left|x\right|\leq 8 , m=0,1 and \int_{0}^{x}(\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)-Y_{0}\left(t\right))\mathrm{d}t , \int_{x}^{\infty}t^{-1}(\mathbf{H}_{0}\left(t\right)-Y_{0}\left(t\right)) \mathrm{d}t , x\geq 8 ; the coefficients are to 20D. ( ) gives Chebyshev-series expansions for \mathbf{L}_{0}\left(x\right) , \mathbf{L}_{1}\left(x\right) , 0\leq x\leq 16 , and I_{0}\left(x\right)-\mathbf{L}_{0}\left(x\right) , I_{1}\left(x\right)-\mathbf{L}_{1}\left(x\right) , x\geq 16 ; the coefficients are to 20D.

( ) gives polynomial approximations for \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right) for n=0,1 , 0\leq x\leq 3 , and rational-fraction approximations for \mathbf{H}_{n}\left(x\right)-Y_{n}\left(x\right) for n=0,1 , x\geq 3.
The maximum errors do not exceed 1.2×10⁻⁸ for the former and 2.5×10⁻⁸ for the latter.
In this section we provide links to the research literature describingthe implementation of algorithms in software for the evaluation of functions described in this chapter.
Citations in bulleted lists refer to papers for which research software has been made available and can be downloaded via the Web.
References to research software that is available in other ways is listed separately.
A more complete list of available software for computing these functions is found in the LABEL:software.
For another listing of Web-accessible software for the functions in this chapter, see .
